p: To estimate the seasonal flu transmission rate, we fit a simple deterministic, network-based, ordinary differential equation (ODE) SEIR model of seasonal flu transmission to national influenza data from the United States. We chose 2008-2009 as it preceded the 2009 pandemic and 2003-2004 as a representative large season [ 29], and specifically analyzed weeks 1-15 of 2009 and week 45 of 2003 through week 3 of 2004. We estimated seasonal influenza incidence (denoted ILI+) throughout these periods by multiplying the CDCâ€™s ILINet estimates of influenza activity by WHO public health lab estimates of percent positive flu tests [ 29], as suggested by [ 66].
